title: Crowd-based Ontology Engineering with the uComp Protege Plugin

author: Marta Sabou, Vienna University of Technology

segmentation: Let me just start by reflecting a little bit on the invited talk that we had this morning, so I'm trying to put a little bit my my work in this perspective.

So one message that I took away from this morning's talk which was by the way, very exciting and interesting, is that our ontology based and knowledge based systems are becoming more complex, more more interesting for other people around us, and therefore it's important to involve a varied set of stakeholders in all the.
Process is related to building this knowledge based systems alright, so.

You saw this this comparison table from Deborah Mcguinnes showing how over the years the role of the knowledge expert has been extended with contributions from communities, community contributions and so on.
And I think the talk that we have seen.
It's an excellent embodiment of this message that the grammar Guinness was trying to bring through.
I hope the authors agree, and in fact our work is very similar with the previous talk that we have seen.
With two very important differences, right?

So one of the differences is that is that they focus Yolanda and Daniel focus on a very well defined ontology engineering task, and they also have in mind a very clearly defined community of experts, right?
And then they apply these crowdsourcing mechanisms to enable ontology engineering.
Now what you wanted to do in our work, which by the way, now that the slides are here has been published in the Semantic Web Journal in 2016.
I want to push this paradigm more towards a generic level, so we wanted to.
Investigate how generic ontology engineering tasks can be solved by a generic crowd of contributors for a layman, crowd of contributors and accordingly we have different quite precise.
Interpretation of what crowdsourcing means.

So we subscribe to the definition of Jehovah, which states that crowdsourcing is the task of taking a job typically performed by an employee, an ontology engineer, for example, and outsourcing it to an undefined, generally large group of people in the form of an open course or not.
Like Daniel and Yolanda, or doing because they already know their experts very well.
So just for those of you who are not familiar with crowdsourcing, what typically happens in this process, is it?
That there's a requester who has a problem that he needs to solve, and then he breaks up this problem into several smaller tasks.
Post this to crowdsourcing platforms, which further provide the tasks to, uh, set to population of workers who solved this task.
Submit the solutions, and then the crowdsourcing platform collects and aggregates this results and provides the solution.
To the requester.
Now this general framework actually has a variety of incarnations, right?

They go from the use of general crowdsourcing platforms like I'm like Crowdflower and Amazon Mechanical Turk to games with a purpose, but also volunteer volunteering citizen science projects like Zooniverse, about which probably most of you have heard.
OK, so why is this interesting for ontology engineering?
Where it turns out that.

Outsourcing is a promising approach for addressing ontology engineering problems and the key problem with ontology engineering is that it's a time consuming and costly process and to demonstrate this, I'd like to ask how many few built on an ontology from scratch.
OK, so you know what I'm talking about.
How about how many of you had your work bootstrapped by automatic ontology learning algorithm that already learned some basic structure?
OK, so you know what I'm talking about, yes?
So even in this case, yes, you end up with a beautiful large ontology.

But then there's a painstaking task of checking whether the terms extracted are relevant for the domain, whether the relations extracted makes sense and also to extend the ontology, which relations that ontology learning algorithms couldn't learn.
As this simple tasks are actually very nicely amenable to crowd sourcing process is so.
It's not a surprise that several approaches have already shown.
That crowd sourcing can be used successfully in various ontology engineering settings, and here I just show a few approaches that we have reviewed in around 2014 when we wrote this paper.
So if your approach is not here, please, it's not our fault, so this is just an an overview of these approaches which come both from different crowdsourcing, sharable.
Both games with a purpose and mechanized labor.
Let me just look closer to one of these approaches.
This is the climate quiz.
This gave me the purpose, which is a Facebook application.
We have built exactly for this scenario where ontologies are learned automatically and then they need to be verified.
So what happened in this quiz?

What this was that players were presented with pairs of terms that the algorithm deemed related and they had to select between 8 relations that might hold between these terms such as subclass relation, part of part of relation but also domain specific relations.
And although this game was quite nice, results from a knowledge acquisition perspective, it took about 3 four months to build and to test.
So this was a little bit of a drawback.
And actually this is a.

Social Point because although we've seen that ontology engineering could offer a lot of interesting problems to crowdsourcing and many, many people showed that crowdsourcing can address these problems.
There's such a high upfront investment in learning this crowdsourcing mechanisms of building these games that these techniques remain out of the reach of most on teologi engineers.
Yes, or simply, they don't have time to learn this domain, and this is exactly the.
Pain point that we wanted to address in our mission was to build crowdsourcing at the fingertips of ontology engineers, right?
So we wanted to understand how to embed.
How could we embed crowd sourcing into ontology engineering?
And for this we have done free things.
So first we wanted to understand what are these typical crowdsourcing task that any many, many people would need to perform.
How could we implement this into some prototype?
And also what would be the impact of this prototype?
And ontology engineering process in terms would be, would it be feasible?
Would it be a scalable?
In particular, this would be the main questions.
OK, so I'm going to summarize the main findings related to these questions related to the first one.

After we reviewed the existing literature up to to that point, we found out that actually most ontology engineering problems can be broken down to a handful of typical crowdsourcing tasks, and I'm just going to illustrate a few of them.
So one of them is specifying term relatedness right.
You have two terms, and you want to find out whether they are related.
The other task refers to verifying relation correctness.
So in this case you already know that these terms are related.
Maybe your ontology learning.
Algorithm deduce this and you want to verify whether this relation is correct.
For example a subsumption relation.
Last but not least, a more complex problem type is when two terms are known to be related and we want to deduce the type of relation that holds between them.
So I called this specifying the type of the relation.
So the fact that we could identify this kind of atomic task was the foundation for the next step of our research, which was to materialize these tasks in a prototype system.
And because we wanted to.
Have such as much impact as possible, we decided.
To build a plugin in Protege and which is, as you know, one of the of the most popular ontology engineering tool and the plug-in has the name of the project that funded this work.
So if you were wondering why it's called you OK, so I'm just going to give you an insight how this plugin works.
In principle an ontology engineer can specify a task that he needs to solve.
Currently we are covering task T2T3 an addition on additional task about domain verification for a term so.
We want to verify whether a term is related to a domain, which is an important task in ontology learning.
And once this task is specified, then the plugin takes care of everything else, so it takes the larger tasks.
It splits it into smaller atomic tasks.
Since this two hour you complete form which can create and launch crowdsourcing tasks automatically, both on mechanized labor platforms and in games with a purpose.
So this is the speciality of this.
You come framework then also the results are collected and aggregated and sent back to Protege.
And present it as a result.
2 don't college engineer who has done the possibility to interpret this, who running out of time?
OK, so just to make this a little bit more concrete, I will show you some screenshots.
So this is the window for specifying.
I think you cannot read too much, but you have to believe me.
This is a window for specifying the task of verifying subsumption relations.
We can verify entire subtrees if needed, and then this is translated in the corresponding crowdsourcing interface is very simple, interfaces that crowd workers can interact with.
The results are collected and then send back to the plugin and presented to the ontology engineering.
Since we had already this prototype, it gave us the possibility.
To perform some evaluation and see how it works, how it would work in practice.

For this evaluation we have selected several smaller ontologies, mostly automatically learned to, to assess the feasibility of the prototype and also larger ontology to have an insight into the scalability of this of this method in terms of the study population, we had a group of eight ontology engineers who performed.
This for tasks that you see there once manually without with just a normal protege and then using the our plugin.
In this case we only send tasks to the crowd flower platform, not two games with a purpose.
And here you can see some of the settings we have used.
What we did was to collect then metrics related to time and cost from both approaches and compare them.
And here we distinguish between metrics that describe just the time and.
Cost of the ontology engineer and also of the entire processing case when also that cost at the time of the crowdsourcing has to be considered.
So in the paper you will have a lot of find, a lot of tables and you can have a lot of fun looking at them.
I hear just.
To capture some Maine.
Things that we learn main results that we have obtained so far the feasibility evaluation.

It became clear that with the plugin you can save tremendously on the time and cost of the ontology engineer, but the downside was that the overall process, the overall duration of the crowd sourcing process, increased in this case tenfold from 20 minutes to 200 something minutes, which might not be so drastic in any case, in all the cases that we looked at, the cost of the overall.
Ontology engineering process was reduced to 60% of the original original cost and also the quality was quite good.
OK, in terms of the scalability.
Evaluation I cannot give you such a clear statement because we found out that it really depends on the complexity of the task that was performed.
And I will go into more detail.
Maybe in the coffee break about this result.
Because I have to sum up now.

So just to summarize where we started from, as I told you at the beginning of the talk, we observed that crowdsourcing requires such a high upfront investment that it remains outside the reach of most ontology engineers and we wanted to change this by answering some some key questions.
I think we can conclude that crowdsourcing can be embedded successfully in ongoing ontology engineering settings thanks to the fact that most.
Ontology engineering process is boiled down to handful of typical tasks which you can implement quite easily into a prototype system.
For example, a plug-in and evaluation although.
Should be repeated and made a little bit statistically.
Most more significant shows that good quality ontologies can be obtained.
Certainly cheaper and relieving the ontology engineer and its involvement in terms of future work.
So we're just coming up from a funding winter and look forward to the revive this line of work.
Maybe with you.
So we are interested on several topics.
For example on using this plugin, could you imagine applying it to one to your own work to your own ontology engineering project, or adapting it?
For example, replacing the crowds, generic routes with expert crowds, and last but not least extending it with support for other ontology engineering tasks.
Such as human centric ontology evaluation or ontology localization.
Thank you and sorry for over an English.
One question is you made several tests with different domains of.
So what do you think about the limits of this in terms of domains?
Do domains need to be general purpose to involve a generic crowd or is it also possible to have very specialized cases?
So I think deliberately we chose for the feasibility evaluation, quite generic domains.
And for the scalability evaluation, we had this anatomy ontology.
But actually many people are sufficiently familiar with these two to have good results.

Having said that, in other domains like engineering and so on, this could be quite difficult, but one way to use this plugin is really to reroute the generated crowdsourcing task to an expert population.
So this is just a generic framework.
We can model and extend and in these cases when we talk about a specialized domain knowledge, it could be changed so that we addressed specialized crowds.
Could you give us a bit more details about how this works?
Say I'm an ontology engineer.
I've built my ontology in protege, so how?
How am I deciding how am I exploring that class hierarchy and decide where to crowd source and whatnot?
And my first question, my second question is, what do you use for the validation?
Of the crowd results.
OK, so let's just take one at the time.
OK, so first for, for the plug in.
So there's each of these functionality's that we support.
They are separate windows that you can involve serve in protege.
So I mean, this also depends a little bit on your on your task and your needs.
We haven't looked into this particular process, so that's why, for example, we have this recursive approach where you can just go to the.

Root class and say validate all all subclasses for this domain or validate all subsumption here hierarchies, or you can just go to part of your ontology that you're not so happy with and just work on that, but you're completely right, there's no methodology behind this, so in this first iteration we just tested our ideas and building methodologies for cloud based ontology engineering.
Certainly would be awarded the next step.
What was the next question?
How do you validate the results?
We validated the results.
Currently we measured agreement between what ontology engineers and crowd workers provided in the event that you have multiple crowd members give different answers.
So how would you know which crowd you can trust?
Which person in the crowd, which person?
How do you determine whose answer is the most trustworthy?
So currently we use majority voting aggregation method that relies on majority voting and.
The answer for which mode most crowd workers voted is selected as possibly the correct one.
So this is a basic aggregation mechanism.
